title: Fast Paced
content: This book is more about the relationship of Joetta ( the mother and wife ) of her family during the civil war.  Her 15 yr. old son leaves one night to join the war and her husband soon follows to bring him back. Joetta and her husband have remained neutral which is the premise of this story. The story is centered in a small town and on Joetta's farm where she and her young son and argumentative father-in-law remain. Being neutral leaves her very vulnerable and causes relationships in the community to cease and property damage to her farm by her community. Joetta remains strong throughout the story while going through so many hardships.

title: Highly recommend
content: Once again Donna Everhart has written a novel that entertains and educates. This novel centers around Joetta McBride and her family in North Carolina before and during the Civil War. I have read many novels set during that period told from the perspective of a slave owner or slave. Donna has told her story from the perspective of a wife of a small farmer who owns no slaves. When talk of war begins, she feels the fight is not their fight, that only the rich landowner has anything to gain or lose from the war. She doesn't take 'sides' and neither does her husband, a view that serves to ostracize them. However, when her oldest son runs away to join the Confederate fight, she is drawn into a battle she never wanted.

title: What is jessamine?
content: Don't expect to find the answer in this book. After slugging through numerous repetitions of the same story, we finally are introduced to Jessamine toward the end of the book. A vine that grew up the columns on the porch of the heroine's house. Titling a chronicle of the harrowing experiences of non-supporters of the rebel cause during the civil war for an insignificance plant is a bit puzzling to me. And I'm not a fan of contrived narratives that magically restore all the suffering and losses experienced during the whole book at the end of it. Nice try, though, of describing how the confederacy treated its own based on rumor and suspicions.
